Professor, thank you for taking the time to personally respond to this thread. It shows how world-class EECS faculty members are. They make you suffer a lot to make you learn but students grow stronger due to it. So thanks.

Professor, please do consider teaching CS 288 in the near future! We are all dying to learn Natural Language Processing. I saw your enthusiasm while teaching language translation at the end of CS 61A. I would give my right kidney to take CS 288 with you.
Prof. DeNero I would love to take CS 288 with you!

I'm glad that holding a town hall led to so much discussion. Thanks to all of you for keeping your remarks (mostly) civil and thoughtful, even when you disagree with each other.

I think these culture and climate issues are important, and I think that more community discussion will help us make progress. That's why I'll be hosting a social hour discussion on elitism this Tuesday (3:30pm in the Woz).  

To be clear, I spend a lot of my time scaling up courses, improving staff hiring, raising money to expand CS education at Cal, and helping to recruit more great faculty. (I might even teach CS 288 one day.) Those issues aren't being neglected. However, I don't think that another town hall is the best way to make progress on them.

@OP I find a lot of the things you said problematic, but I just want to address one piece with empirical evidence that hopefully makes you reconsider your position. From your first post:

"When [a female student] suggested including a woman on the interview board for one of these organizations she was told that "men and women don't interview differently" so there’s no need to include a woman on the board, and that she should "stop pulling the girl card for everything."
What's so controversial here? People should be chosen based on merits, not gender. ALL people are created equal. This includes people of all genders, sexualities and ethnic backgrounds.

Women are often scrutinized more critically than men. Interviews are essential the scrutiny of an individual. A woman’s likability in the workplace isn’t tied to her knowledge or boldness or ability to lead, instead, she is rewarded for projecting warmth but penalized for seeming ambitious (more here). Employees must be seen as likable as well as skilled to be hired or promoted—competence alone is insufficient. We might like to think we live in a meritocracy (standardized by technical coding interviews, perhaps), but there are many fundamental attribution errors we as humans make. More generally, it is easy to think that attitude(s) → behavior, but that misses many essential pieces–like social norms, behavior control, and implicit attitudes. Institutionalized sexism is real, but there are things we can do to lessen the effects it has.

Products are also built for both men and women (generally). When assessing "merit" or what an individual can contribute to a company, the perspective they bring is also essential and can't be forgotten.

Some other things you might be interested in reading:

  • The abrasiveness trap: High-achieving men and women are described differently in reviews: men are given constructive suggestions, women are given critical suggestions. Applies to general feedback, too.
  • Heidi vs Howard: given identical resumes except for the names (“Howard” vs “Heidi”), students rated Howard as someone they’d enjoy as a colleague, while *they said* Heidi seemed less appealing, selfish, and abrasive–and they wouldn't hire her.
  • Male students consistently underestimate female peers (full here): men rank their male classmates as more knowledgeable about course content, even over better-performing female students, over-ranking by ~three-quarters of a GPA point. From the researchers: "To stay in STEM you have to believe you can do it, and one of the things that can convince you of that is your peers saying you can do it. Helping students find peers who believe in them is really important, especially for women, because they're not likely to get that from males in their class." (imagine how this might play out in study groups, project partners, etc.)

P.S. If you want to talk with someone who both disagrees with you and is a woman/ethnic minority in CS, I'm happy to :)

and since this is such a common sentiment and we have already recognized that people are not content with the current climate, I think it makes sense for the department to take some responsibility in educating people within the department because these people largely contribute to the climate.

+1

Thank you Chonyi, I hope that what you've mentioned materializes into concrete action items from the department's end & are institutionalized with a transparent timeline.  

From my experience as serving as an ASUC senator, the fact of the matter is that student's come and go, they graduate, we graduate - but the one constant that will always remain is the Department, the one constant that can be shaped to reflect the impact & culture that we want to have lies in the Department which has a large role in our education from inside & outside the classroom. The Department is in a position to implement these ideas that Chonyi has mentioned, we have dedicated roles within the administration to spearhead these issues - when can we begin?

+1

Staff has the most responsibility to establish the culture, educate students, and broaden their worldviews.

+1

and better curriculum in general (I heard LSCS does not even have the 1-unit ethics requirement as EECS major does)

I don't think taking an ethics course makes someone a better person per se. Sure, you might get to argue the merits of Aristotle's vs Kant's views of morality but does that really make you a good person? No. Making someone a good person isn't as simple as having them take a class. If that was the case, politicians across America would be scrambling to offer this magic solution to their criminals. You want more ethical people, I get it, but my point is forcing someone to take a ethics class defeats the point.

Several thoughts @ latest anon:

> Sure, you might get to argue the merits of Aristotle's vs Kant's views of morality...

It doesn't seem like you've taken an ethics course! Engineering ethics aren't frequently taught in abstract utilitarianism/deontology debates (especially those as anachronistic as Aristotle & Kant), but rather via more recent scholarship and various case studies. CS 195, for example, does a great job of this.

> ...but does that make you a good person?

This is a straw-person argument. Nobody (in this thread or otherwise) is making the claim that requiring an understanding of ethics makes everyone good people automatically––clearly even engineers who understand ethics can and do make unethical decisions.

Ethics courses offer a combination of frameworks (e.g. deontological/utilitarian thought) and postmortems that are helpful for people who want to be good. When we, in our careers, ask ourselves "am I making the ethical decision? am I a good person if I build this tool?," ethics requirements will have built the skills necessary to answer those questions to our own satisfaction. Feel free to make the claim that this thinking is trivial and can be achieved via some good ol' fashioned engineering intuition––the thousands of years of moral philosophy you cite, an extremely dense recent interest in STEM ethics (esp. bioethics), and various ongoing violations of ethical standards in STEM indicate otherwise

Whatever "good" means, that is.

> If that was the case, politicians across America would be scrambling to offer this magic solution to their criminals.

This is a red herring. Ethics classes exist to make engineering students more ethical engineers; if whatever "criminals" you're referring to are engineering students (they very well might be), then engineering ethics classes make a lot of sense for them!

Furthermore, even if we take your extension as valid/logical, there are lots of programs teaching moral philosophy and ethics in American prisons as part of rehabilitation/education programs.

And, finally, since when are politicians experts on engineering ethics? Why do you defer to their authority? This impulse seems misguided, especially given the various violations of engineering ethics that have been and continue to be commissioned by a number of governments.

> You want more ethical people, I get it, but my point is forcing someone to take a ethics class defeats the point.

Yes, it is good when people are ethical. Is your argument that exposing people to ethics will cause them to be unethical? That it'll have no impact on their personal ethics? You haven't indicated either, even in your fallacious comparison.

Can the department hold a townhall or workshop or something dedicated to just educating people within our field, students and staff, on how race, gender, sexuality, etc. intersect and show up in the forms of implicit bias, imposter syndrome, meritocracy myths, unequal access to education and opportunities, respectability politics, etc etc etc.  I understand that so many people here come from backgrounds where they weren't confronted with / exposed to these issues, but honestly the sentiments/ignorance expressed by op is really common in this department.  And as a senior it's tiring, frustrating, and discouraging to see this same conversation have to happen SO MANY times whether it be on here, on the facebook cs group, in person.  It would be nice for there to be like one space (even a pinned piazza post?, just something easily accessible?) that has information and resources for people like op to read through and learn, and then express whatever opinions they have after having a certain level of understanding.  Also would be important for the department to intentionally promote and validate it.  It just feels like someone always expresses an opinion like this, and then people in the comments have to start from scratch in educating this person, and then it happens again a little later.  And also this wouldn't just be for op, but also for underrepresented minorities because the department definitely feels less inviting than it already is when their people believe things like "underrepresented minorities simply are not interested in cs!"

Omg...did I hit a piazza post limit. This got cut off. That's embarrassing. 

And frustrating. :( I'll re-add the rest later.

Michael, thank you for your post. You mentioned tech companies are reaching out to minority groups more, which is great. What are your thoughts on internship / job programs that only accept minority students, however. Some internship programs are reserved for minority students, just based on their race, which is a large cause of the anger felt by the OP and others.

Also, Michael, how would you suggest we deal with people lying about their race to gain advantage in tech? This has been happening in university admissions for a while and also in politics (see Elizabeth Warren). Based on the increasing advantages being a minority student in tech holds today, just based on recruiters actively reaching out to you, the incentive to lie about one's race is growing.

The last section that was cut off:

It's possible, in fact I'd say extremely likely, almost certain, that the resource allocation is biassed towards the majority. This isn’t necessarily nefarious, more a byproduct of societal and system imbalances. It’s true that there may be some “give and take” in terms of what needs to change to be better supportive of more groups and individuals. We are all (or were) struggling college students and trying to get into classes. The unfortunate reality is that some groups experience disadvantages that others do not. You can claim this is natural, and to an extent you’d be right. However, what’s not natural are the extreme gender and racial imbalances in our program (and others). What’s not natural, is recognizing that discrimination exists, but ignoring to do anything about it.

What’s different about the issues now, is that there are a critical mass of a bunch of different marginalized groups. Keep in mind that not everyone at these town halls and social hours is experiencing the same struggles and difficulties. It’s a wide range of issues, but there are very common unifying elements that I believe demand the attention of everyone in our community. While I was not at this town hall, I was at the one immediately prior, and so far these have been the two best attended town halls in my recent memory. The have been better attended by faculty, staff, students, and administrators. There were a couple years not too long ago where the department didn’t have a town hall because attendance was so low. 

Finally, I wanted to reiterate that these topics are tough and I truly mean that my inbox is open if you’d like to send a message.

Thanks for reading. <3.

—

Follow Up:

It was brought to me that my comparison to advocating for diverse political view points on campus is an unfair comparison. I was not trying to convey nor imply that those with traditionally conservative viewpoints have faced the system biases that other marginalized groups have. That’s not fair comparison. I was trying to convey that we ought to have diversity in many ways. People are intersectional - “the isms” cross many different boundaries that can apply to people in many ways. We need to make sure that those who are not like us, are included in our communities.

Ok to the questions:

Edit: mixing up my piazza posts. lol. Just like the ol' days.

Perverse Incentives to Lie.

I like to think of this the same way I deal with cheating as a TA/Instructor. My experience is that most people don't cheat, and most cheating doesn't tip the scales in a significant way. Regardless of whether you add race or gender to the mix, what we're talking about is people cheating an application system. People can (and do) do this already. However, the question is about prevalence and the how effective the cheating is. Most people don't lie, and those who do lie about their race or socioeconomic status or fabricate essays for college were probably not as strong of applicants to being with. I also very much fundamentally believe that most  people are well intentioned and not evil. That helps me stay grounded at times..because:

People lying to gain an advantage is a real problem. Turns out, for a nominal sum of cash (say $1500) it's pretty easy to get certified as having ADHD. Aside from the access to prescription drugs, this enables people to unfairly apply for disability accommodations. 150% time on a test can certainly be an advantage when you're not using it to overcome a disability. The result of this, is that getting accommodations can be excessively difficult. It took nearly a year (and letters and phone calls from my parents to many people at the College Board) to get approved, and they still eff'd up my SATs and AP tests many times.

So, the consequences of these actions are real. To me, the solution is that if you find someone is lying or cheating, you punish them. When it comes to race (and even more so, gender identity) is can be difficult and touchy to verify, but if a company has a problem that is so bad to the point where they need to take these measures, I think they can communicate with applicants about their process. I would much rather see process try to adapt to be equitable, and then correct their mistakes instead of trying nothing at all.  In my view: if an application asks for a gender, and it's progressive enough to even include an option for transgender, I just can't fathom that many people (I just say it...) are fucked up enough to co-opt the incredible struggles of the trans community for their own gain? I'm not saying it won't happen, but until it happens on a big scale, I personally think  the impact that you make by being equitable would outweigh the potential costs.

However, the other option is to change the incentive structure. Getting a job will always have a high financial incentive to it, but I think it just means that we have to adjust the process to lower the stakes. I read that the average American now has 10 jobs before they're 40. This hopefully means that landing in the wrong first job won't be such a deal. It's part education and part process change that I think can ultimately solve the problems. 

On programs that are only for a certain race or group:
I don't personally have strong feelings about these overall. My personal belief is that the more we interact with others not like us, the more we will collectively understand each other better. However, programs that cater to a specific demographic and be extremely successful. In the space on early-CS education there are a number of programs such as CODE2040, Black Girls Code, AppCamp for Girls, Level the Playing Field Institute. These programs are, in part, able to achieve success by simply removing the racial, gender, economic and other tensions so so they can focus on their goals of teaching  programming.  In think internship and scholarship programs that are structured the same way are also a necessary component of progress. They give people opportunities they otherwise wouldn't have. And in terms of resources, I don't think those programs typically take away spots from everyone else - I think they're more of an additive thing. Like "we're going to do this extra effort because we believe in this case", such that if not centered around a gender/ethic/etc issue, then there wouldn't be a replacement program.

Michael, thank you for writing such a detailed answer.

I would disagree that the programs you mention remove racial/gender/economic tensions. They increase them. People don't usually look at people based on their race but when you divide people into groups like this, and give specific groups opportunities, then you interracial anger that never even existed in the first place. There should be special programs for the disadvantaged in general, so dividing along economic lines is fine, however let's not make assumptions like "he's a Latino student, hence we need to help him out instead of this poor white student".

@^Anon: Affirmative action is not aimed at the individual, or at the present for that matter.

What a lot of people seem to miss is the fact that the point of affirmative action is to attempt to compensate for historical, systematic oppression/discrimination against a people. The idea is, when you oppress a group of people for hundreds of years and then realize you've been doing something morally wrong, you can't just stop, apologize, and then pretend as if that is sufficient to right your wrong... you actually need to compensate. This may or may not involve some intermediate effects such as increasing diversity or helping the needy/poor, and one might argue those are themselves noble goals worth pursuing, but they are side effects, not the goals themselves here. The goal is to right a historical moral wrong, and its scope and effects extend beyond individuals or the current generation. If the present was similar but the history wasn't there, affirmative action could very well not be there either.

Merhdad is right about the fact that the goal here is to correct systemic and historical biases. But, I think the goal of programs directed at certain individuals go beyond affirmative action practices. 

When I said it removes tensions, I meant in the context of that particular environment, not across society. However, I sincerely doubt that these programs do increase racial, economic or other divides in a meaningful way. Why is OK to group 'disadvantaged' into one large group or to not consider race? I would agree that socioeconomic status is probably a better indicator of disadvantage, but it's so intertwined with race, that I don't think it matters much in aggregate. 

But furthermore, 'disadvantaged' is a catch-all term, like marginalized that captures dozens and dozens of different disadvantages. While the blind and visually impaired have instances of discrimination and microaggressions, they're not same struggles that black youth, or Latinxs, or any other group face, even though they're in a similar category. 

Specific programs give people a place to share and grow and hopefully include support without the discomfort of needing to explain to others the struggles they've encountered. For example, while I would to teach CS at many of them, my presence would be an active distraction for many of the students.

If as a society, we segregated ourselves all the time, in every way, then you're right that'd we probably be in a worse position overall. But programs that address a specific group aren't designed to replace people's interaction with others - they're a temporary. Someone who goes through an internship targeted at women, will almost certainly be working with and interacting with and possibly even dating men then or in the future. Additionally, people are intersectional, I don't believe that individuals in these programs see themselves as only that adjective.

Finally-- the the quote "people don't see race". People absolutely notice people who don't look or act like them. It doesn't matter whether you think you're an enlightened person; we all have unconscious biases we are (by definition) we are unaware of. What do you think when you walk by a homeless person, or see a group of African American dancers on BART, or someone using a red and white cane, etc, etc? Some of these things you and I probably think are normal, but for some of them we have instinctive reactions we probably don't even notice. It's very difficult to become aware of these things, but damn, I've carried around some very ill-conceived thoughts and reactions.

Since this has come up, and I've written similar things on FB, I feel like I might as well share my story, and some thoughts, because I feel like there is a lot of misinformation about certain things.

Also, if you want to privately chat or send me hate mail, find me on FB / Twitter or my Berkeley email. ball@berkeley. I'm here for y'all. :)


“I didn't have time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead.”

― Mark Twain



Background on who I am for those who do not know me, so that you can judge me an my comments as you wish:
In my 5 years at Berkeley, I did a 5th year Masters (in CS Edu), TA'd CS10 for 3 years taught it over summer, and was a semi-TA for a year. I've presented at a faculty retreat, met with the chancellor and have spent a lot of time with faculty and staff talking about culture, climate, TAing and education. I am a slightly above average height white cis-gendered male from a stable family raised in a moderately affluent town. I had the full support of parents to attend school, but also received some financial aid. I wear metal framed glasses and shorts, and based on all this I could so incredibly easily disappear in the sea of CS students. I like that actually, there's comfort in being able to disappear. However, I also have a somewhat hidden and certainly not very obvious disability- I'm very visually impaired. It affects things you wouldn't expect.

I have since graduated, but continue to work part time with Dan Garcia on CS Education projects and have lunch with faculty.

That's probably the most important bits, and far too long, sorry.

---
To the OP: What you feel is natural and understandable. I've been there too. You are not wrong that waitlists and the pressure to graduate on time and take courses are real and important struggles. We all face them too. I am not going to try to quantify which of these issues are most important. I don't think it's helpful to - because there are no good objective ways to measure the relative size and importance of these issues. People are all affected to different degrees by these issues, and even if based something solely on a survey, we can't ignore issues that receive less votes -- they deserve time too regardless of their nature.

On the particular aspect of dealing with course sizes and waitlists: Rest assured that your concerns are understood by everyone, and there is not a day that has gone by in the past few years where faculty and staff are not concerned by this issue.

Diversity and inclusion are not merely about being politically correct. When a group is marginalized, it's important to make a conscious effort include marginalized groups and individuals otherwise you end up with a tyranny of the majority. This is not always by direct actions of the major, but simply by indirect privileges that come from strength in numbers. (In some cases, i.e. Slavery, internment camps, disenfranchisement and voting laws the actions are actually very explicit...) When only one Black student walks across the stage at graduation, we need to make sure we're aware that they aren't the only black student who was capable of studying CS. Under this logic, I am very much agreeing that the UC Berkeley Campus as whole would benefit from having more politically conservative students. As much as I really do despite the current Republican platform, we benefit from the ability to discuss with and learn from differently minded individuals.

As a TA, I relished the opportunity to speak with and indeed learn from from students who brought view points I'd never considered. Some of these were senior english majors comparing CS to writing, others were women sharing their general college experiences. I'm not going to totally address the importance of diversity, because this is long enough, but there are numerous reports about "the business case for diversity" that provide a good starting point. Furthermore, we can't blame a lack of diversity on individuals or on external factors. At some point, this has turned into the "pipeline problem", which ultimately comes down to family choices and circumstances of upbringing, and since no one can control those - blaming the pipeline leads to the logical conclusion that this is no one's problem to solve. No one has ownership of the pipeline, because we're part of the collective pipe-circle (?) of life. Many studies have shown that the reason there are less women in CS fields is not because they are less interested, but that they self-select out due to various cultural reasons. These women (or young girls in many cases) show interest in science long before they choose another field.

These town halls are important, because these issues that are being described have been prevalent for a long while. They are now coming to a head because I believe there is a critical mass of marginalized individuals. In my 5+ years, this was the first time I've seen a discussion as large as this, and one that is sincerely interested in making progress. In my own experience, the number of students with disability accommodations in CS is way lower than you would expect based on campus statistics. I've had many remarks made to me about accommodations giving me an unfair advantage despite there being legal mandates and procedures which are (for the most part) internationally consistent. (Not all accommodations are, but mine are fairly standard.) Yes, I got 1.5x time on exams and sat in a different room. Usually. No, it's not as glorious and you think, and no you most certainly do not want to specifically schedule every freaking exam. Nor do you want the SATs to take two days, for example. I'm grateful that faculty are accommodating and in most cases willing to learn. But it's an uphill battle. Sometimes it's far easier to just forgo any legally mandated accommodations and pretend to be normal, nasty headaches or lower scores be dammed.
I don't want to sound like I'm complaining, but I'm not trying to. My visual impairment is very manageable and even the awkwardness that it does impose could be far worse. My point is that most people cannot see this.

I cannot see, nor can I truly understand all the struggles that some people may go through to attend Berkeley. It may be the many additional jobs (for which my lazy ass probably couldn't handle), or it may jus be the way that others are treated by their peers or something else. It is entirely within our control, however, to create a place where these factors are mitigated and where we learn to address them. This doesn't mean affirmative action necessarily, or any particular policy - but by doing nothing would be systematically harm a bunch of different individuals in a bunch of different ways.


As a point of clarification: As it stands right now CA Prop 209 passed by voters in 1996, an anti-discrimination law, forbids affirmative action policies by higher education institutions. (Among other things). So, yes, considering race for admissions is currently illegal. But, consequently, allowing discrimination is also illegal. While I'm not aware of any codified department policies that would constitute illegal discrimination, I do believe that we have a social culture which allows such actions to continue. We have course policies and course designs (both implicit and explicit) that can lead to unintended discrimination.

It's also simply unfair to equate improving diversity with lowering bar. Many of the (often small) gains that STEM departments and tech companies have seen in improving diversity are not through changing standards, but simply doing more to reach out to and search for groups that are typically not included. We can go to black students, or disabled students, or women or whomever and say "I think you might enjoy computer science. It's a really interesting subject that you probably haven't had a chance to explore, but here's why it's awesome. If you like it, I want to make sure that we'll do what we can to make sure you feel like a part of the community." It might feel like awkward special treatment at first, but the goal isn't to do this forever, necessarily. The goal is do this until we have an equitable community. The reason accommodations for disabled students exist, is to level the playing field - so to speak. Many of the marginalized groups come from backgrounds where they never had access to computer science, for any number of reasons. Though not a physical or learning disability, a lack of access to the traditional support structures is very much a handicap in one's education. If we believe that discrimination is immoral, then so would it be immoral to not address these systemic problems.

At the end of the day, some of these resources we are talking about (such as time and money) are finite. And if we are talking about moving money from one student org to another, you're right to be concerned about the opportunity costs such a move would present. In the case of funds, I think there are two things consider:
a) every financial allocation is a different story, a different beast with different trade-offs. It's not worth too much effort considering the abstract case here, because the implementation is vitally important. There are outcomes which might benefit everyone in unexpected ways.
b) On principle, if we assume that money is to be spent in a way that is equally beneficial to all students, then we need to examine whether we are currently achieving that goal. Some folks have very clearly demonstrated that existing structures (a la HKN) do not support their needs -- and they are just as much entitled to XYZ as we are to HKN.

OP - it sounds like you have some preformed (idealistic) ideas of a perfectly meritocratic world. Join an organization and see how that organization undergoes the vetting of new members into the organization. Its a fact of human psychology that we prefer people who are more like us, even though we suppress this preference on a conscious level, it is subconsciously influencing our decisions. I had very similar views to yours until I joined a new organization on campus. The organization was founded on views of diversity and inclusivity, but what ended up happening was that diversity simply did not happen as new batches of members came in - people subconsciously associated with similar people and the latter batches of the organization looked far more homogenous than the first diverse group of founding members.

history.content:
I attended the CS town hall meeting on Tuesday. Minutes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1i9hiXp6bgFLsSe6i91gy7HaGVTpCiUw2gJi-aZDVPLE/edit

Why is everyone so politically correct at these town hall meetings? We have so many more important things to discuss. How can we more regularly offer courses [like CS 288]? How can we deal with long waitlists? How can we afford more tuition waivers for TAs? These are the real issues CS students want to discuss. Open forums with Professors are rare. I, and most CS students, would rather not waste the chance on safe spaces/playing victim card/dividing people by race, gender, sexuality.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"EECS Master Race” is offensive/hurtful to those inside and outside of our department"

Relax, it's just a joke. No one ever meant harm.

"As a female and a minority I definitely feel like I don't belong when none of my TAs or professors look like me.”

This is a non-issue. TAs and Professors are hired on their merits, not on gender or color of their skin. Also, it's not all about race. People can be similar without having the same skin color.

"When [a female student] suggested including a woman on the interview board for one of these organizations she was told that "men and women don't interview differently" so there’s no need to include a woman on the board, and that she should "stop pulling the girl card for everything."

What's so controversial here? People should be chosen based on merits, not gender. ALL people are created equal. This includes people of all genders, sexualities and ethnic backgrounds.

"TAs are dismissive or lack understanding/empathy, this can be especially difficult for those who come in without CS backgrounds or underrepresented students"

I've been at Cal 3 years and not once have I had a bad TA. In any of my CS courses. Not once. Our TAs are the most energetic, enthusiastic, and intelligent people I've ever known at Cal. These are people that write books for students (like Sinho Chewi, Alvin Wan), respond to Slack/text messages at all hours of the day, and answer your piazza questions without even being students (Steven Bi). I attended the CS town hall meeting on Tuesday. Minutes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1i9hiXp6bgFLsSe6i91gy7HaGVTpCiUw2gJi-aZDVPLE/edit

Why is everyone so politically correct at these town hall meetings? We have so many more important things to discuss. How can we more regularly offer courses [like CS 288]? I, and most CS students, would rather not waste the chance on safe spaces/playing victim card/dividing people by race, gender, sexuality.

Relax, it's just a joke. No one ever meant harm.

This is a non-issue. TAs and Professors are hired on their merits, not on gender or color of their skin. Also, it's not all about race. People can be similar without having the same skin color.

"When [a female student] suggested including a woman on the interview board for one of these organizations she was told that "men and women don't interview differently" so there’s no need to include a woman on the board, and that she should "stop pulling the girl card for everything."

What's so controversial here? People should be chosen based on merits, not gender. ALL people are created equal. This includes people of all genders, sexualities and ethnic backgrounds.

"TAs are dismissive or lack understanding/empathy, this can be especially difficult for those who come in without CS backgrounds or underrepresented students"

I've been at Cal 3 years and not once have I had a bad TA. In any of my CS courses. Not once. Our TAs are the most energetic, enthusiastic, and intelligent people I've ever known at Cal. These are people that write books for students (like Sinho Chewi, Alvin Wan), respond to Slack/text messages at all hours of the day, and answer your piazza questions without even being students (Steven Bi). Please find someone else to blame. We CS students love our TAs.

"Students from BESSA (Black Engineering and Sciences Student Association) expressed that they feel that enough is not being done....Reported that BESSA lacks the resources to provide services like tutoring, given their few numbers."

Okay....Whose fault is that?

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

history.content:
I attended the CS town hall meeting on Tuesday. Here are the minutes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1i9hiXp6bgFLsSe6i91gy7HaGVTpCiUw2gJi-aZDVPLE/edit

Why is everyone so politically correct at these town hall meetings? We have so many more important things to discuss. How can we regularly offer courses like NLP? How can we offer more courses? How can we deal with long waitlists? These are the issues CS students care about. NOT safe spaces/playing victim card/dividing people by race, gender, sexuality.

"EECS Master Race” is offensive/hurtful to those inside and outside of our department"

It's a joke! Why are you guys taking it so seriously?

"As a female and a minority I definitely feel like I don't belong when none of my TAs or professors look like me.”

TAs and Professors are hired on their merits, not on gender or color of their skin. Also, people can be similar without having the same skin color. It's not all about race.

"When the leadership board [of an EECS student organization] is all-male, it's often uncomfortable for a woman to suggest or promote changes. When she suggested including a woman on the interview board for one of these organizations she was told that "men and women don't interview differently" so there’s no need to include a woman on the board, and that she should "stop pulling the girl card for everything."

What's so controversial here? Let's focus on people's merits not their gender.
history.subject: Why are CS Town Hall meetings so politically correct?
